note.p: William Lewis Sharkey served as Mississippi’s governor in 1865, early in the Reconstruction era.

Born in Sumner County, Tennessee, on July 12, 1798, Sharkey moved with his family to Warren County, Mississippi, in 1804. As an adult, he studied law and began practicing in Natchez, Mississippi, in 1822. Sharkey moved to Vicksburg in 1825 and pursued political office. He won election to the Mississippi House of Representatives and served one term from 1828 to 1829.

In 1832, Sharkey married Minerva Cage, a widow with two children. The couple had four children over the next several years. In 1832, Sharkey also became a circuit court judge and was shortly thereafter elected to the High Court of Errors and Appeals, the predecessor to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. He served in that role for 18 years, resigning in 1851. From there, he took a diplomatic appointment for the United States government, serving as U.S. Consul in Havana, Cuba, until 1854. After completing that diplomatic assignment, Sharkey returned to Mississippi and returned to legal and political duties, helping compile the Mississippi Code of 1857.

During the secession crisis in the winter of 1860 and 1861, following Abraham Lincoln’s election, Sharkey remained a steadfast Unionist. Having been a member of the Whig Party, he retained his opposition to secession and refused to support the Confederacy, even as he remained in Mississippi through the Civil War. Despite his political stance against Mississippi’s secessionist government, Confederate officials left him alone out of respect of his past service to the state as a judge and legal scholar.

After the Confederacy’s defeat, President Andrew Johnson appointed Sharkey provisional governor of Mississippi in June 1865. In that role, he called forth a constitutional convention to meet Johnson’s goal of swiftly restoring former Confederate states to the Union. In October 1865, Benjamin Humphreys won election as Mississippi’s governor. Sharkey did not vacate the office, though, until December 1865, having served less than a year. Although no longer governor, Sharkey was selected by the Mississippi legislature to serve in the U.S. Senate. Federal officials denied him a seat, and the rest of the Mississippi congressional delegation, following the Republican backlash to Mississippi’s Black Codes—a set of racially discriminatory laws passed by the Mississippi legislature in 1865.

Having been denied a U.S. Senate seat, Sharkey returned to practicing law, in Jackson, Mississippi. He died in Washington, D.C., on March 30, 1873, and is buried at Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; David Sansing, “William Lewis Sharkey: Twenty-fifth Governor of Mississippi: June to December 1865,” Mississippi History Now; FindaGrave)
William Lewis Sharkey belonged to the following social groups:

Charles De La Boulay Fontaine was a Mississippi state legislator and officer in the Confederate army. Born on December 28, 1817, in Hanover County, Virginia, Fontaine was the great grandson of notable American Revolutionary War figure Patrick Henry. He moved to Mississippi as a young man and eventually became active in Democratic politics. He served as a state representative in the mid-1840s and then unsuccessfully ran for other political offices, including a failed bid for circuit judge in 1853 and a run for Alabama’s governor as a “Know Nothing” (anti-immigration) candidate.

Following Abraham Lincoln’s election to the presidency in November 1860, Moore was appointed a delegate to Alabama’s secession convention. When the state declared its separation from the Union, Moore volunteered for military service in Pontotoc County and was elected a lieutenant in the “Pontotoc Minute Men.” He continued to serve as an officer in the Confederate army through the Civil War.
He was married to Sarah Anne Dandridge and had twelve children. Moore died in August 1871 at the age of 53. He is buried at Pontotoc City Cemetery in Pontotoc, Mississippi.
(FindaGrave, The Clarion, Jackson, MS, August 31, 1871)

note.p: James Gordon was a Confederate officer and a United States Senator from Mississippi.

Born in Cotton Gin Port, Mississippi, on December 6, 1833, Gordon attended various schools in Mississippi and Alabama before graduating from the University of Mississippi in 1855. He worked as a newspaper writer and then served in the Mississippi House of Representatives in the late 1850s. During the Civil War, Gordon was commissioned as an officer in the Chickasaw Guards, attached to a Mississippi cavalry regiment known as the Jeff Davis Guards, and then was a lieutenant colonel in the Second Mississippi Cavalry Regiment.

In 1864, southern officials sent Gordon to Europe to lobby on behalf of the Confederacy. He was captured by Union forces in Wilmington, North Carolina, in January 1865, but successfully escaped and traveled to Canada. He was there when the war ended, and returned to the United States to face charges of conspiring in the death of Abraham Lincoln due to evidence that he had met with John Wilkes Booth, Lincoln’s assassin, while in Canada. Gordon admitted that while in Montreal he had discussed plans with Booth to kidnap the president, but denied having any knowledge of the assassination. Federal officials eventually dropped their charges against Gordon.

Gordon held various Mississippi public offices in the late nineteenth century, including serving in the state House of Representatives. Most notably, in 1909, at the age of 76, he received an appointment to fill a vacancy in the U.S. Senate following the death of Mississippi senator Anselm J. McLaurin. He was in the Senate for only eight weeks, when the Mississippi legislature elected LeRoy Percy to take the seat.

Gordon died on November 28, 1912. He was married twice, first to Carolina Virginia Wiley, who passed away in 1903. He then married Ella Narcissa Neilson in 1904. Gordon had at least two children who survived to adulthood.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; Biographical Directory of the United States Congress, 1774-Present)
James Gordon belonged to the following social groups:
Located in Pontotoc County, Pontotoc was founded in the 1830s and serves as the county seat. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: "The crime of taking something that does not belong to you, but not in a way that involves force or the threat of force." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The crime of stealing from somewhere or someone." (Cambridge Dictionary)

While the U.S. Constitution grants each chamber some unique power, the House and Senate are equal partners in the legislative process as both chambers are required to enact legislation. U.S. Congress divides legislators into separate committees who write federal or national legislation, and a vast industry of lobbyists also help members write legislation on behalf of corporate and labor interests. Once written, the proposed legislation is introduced to both houses, and if the bill passes both chambers by a majority vote, it is sent to the U.S. President for passage, veto, or pocket-veto, and Congress can overcome the President's veto with a two-thirds majority vote. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Legislation. United States. Congress. General Amnesty Act (1865)

gloss.p: The United States Congress General Amnesty Act (1865) was enacted by President Andrew Johnson on May 29, 1865, giving amnesty (or an official pardon) to former Confederates who participated in the Civil War following an oath of allegiance to the United States and the acceptance of the abolition of enslavement. This act excluded high-ranking military leaders and officials, as well as those who committed war crimes. Johnson believed that amnesty was the surest way to rebuild the nation and the General Amnesty Act was one part of his Reconstruction Plan. This act was welcomed by many Northerners who wanted to move on from the Civil War, but was criticized by many radicals who felt the act was too lenient on Confederate actors and wanted those people excluded from society and punished for their actions in the war. (Wikipedia; National Archives)
"The act of officially choosing someone for a job, or the job itself." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A public officer who judges local and less important legal cases, and performs marriage ceremonies." (Cambridge Dictionary)
A person who oversees "the process of managing the property, money, etc. of someone who has died and giving it to the beneficiaries." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., an official whose job is to be in charge of performing the orders of the law courts and making certain that the laws are obeyed within a particular county." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"An official organization whose job is to manage a particular activity, suggest laws related to the activity, and make certain that laws are obeyed" concerning law enforcement. (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)

element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Sharkey Collection. Petition from the citizens and civil officers of Pontotoc County, Mississippi, to Mississippi Governor William L. Sharkey, asking that he appoint a District Judge and recommending William H. Kilpatrick for the position.

div.p:
Hon Wm L. Sharkey
Provisional Governor

The undersigned Mem=bers of the Board Civil Officers of the Coun-ty of Pontotoc respectfully represent that this and the Contiguous Counties of this the 9th Judicial District are Exposed to the Commission of all manner of public and private wrongs; Among which Lar=cenies and highway Robberies are of al=most dayly occurrence. The repetition of these and other offences has greatly increased, Since by the promulgation of Your proclamation it has come to be understood that our late Circuit Judges are not embraced in the Enumeration of Civil Officers, who are Continued in Office upon their taking the Amnesty = Oath.

We therefore respectfully pray Your Excellency, that You will with as little delay as practicable, appoint a Judge for this District; And we Respectfully recom=mend for the place the present Incumbent the Hon. Wm H Kilpatrick, who we are authorized to say is ready and willing, as by his public antecedents, he is entitled to take the Amnesty Oath

J. A. Mitchell
Pres Board Police
A Y Donaldson Sheriff
John S. Neely P. Judge

C. T Bond J. P.
J H Garrett J. P.
W A Bacon Prob Clk
J A Robbin a member of Pol Board
J A Green
James Gordon
Petition of three of the members of the Pontotoc Bor for the appoint=ment of a Circuit Judge for the 9th District and recom=mending Judge Kilpatrick therefor
